Fuser and Isolater - Which One Are You?

Posted by Emma

Every relationship is made up of two kinds of people- the fuser, and the isolater.

Fuser- defined +causes

Isolater- defined +causes

Why do fusers and isolators marry each other? because they sense that they need the other person in order to achieve balance.

Being either one is not a healthy state of being, it comes as a result of an emotional need to either validation or safety. By marrying someone with the opposite problem as you, you are forced to address the issues and work on becoming more balanced and healthy.

  • Read more about Fuser and Isolater - Which One Are You?

Problems with In-laws?

Posted by Emma

Are in-laws getting in the way?

How to maintain harmony with your spouse AND your in-laws

As if I don't have enough problems with my own parents? Now I need to deal with all the dynamics of my spouses family? (And if I thought my family had problems....)

As one very wise woman said: "A mother shouldn't get into a fight with the woman who is giving him (her son) sex."

The Overbearing In-Laws- setting boundaries that work for you .

Don't critisize your partner's parents in front of him, this will only ignite his defenses.

Alison Armstrong’s Understanding Women Unlock the Mystery Review

Posted by Emma

 

Understanding Women Unlock the Mystery is quite possibly one of the most amazing relationship workshops you’ll ever experience. Given by relationship expert Alison Armstrong, you’ll walk away with a completly different understanding of  how men and women view the world – and practical solutions to help understand each other better.

Throughout the workshop, Alison explains the emotional makeup of women, shedding light on specific female behaviours that men often find confusing and annoying.

  • Read more about Alison Armstrong’s Understanding Women Unlock the Mystery Review

Alison Armstrong's Keys to the Kingdom Review

Posted by Emma

Keys to the Kingdom



In Keys to the Kingdom, Alison Armstrong describes the stages that men go through as they age. The book is written in the form of a story which makes it an easy and pleasant read.

The storyline follows a turning point in the lives of two women - middle-aged Karen, who is struggling to understand her husband’s confusing behavior and Claudia, an older, spirited woman who holds a treasure trove of knowledge on understanding men.

  • Read more about Alison Armstrong's Keys to the Kingdom Review
  • Add new comment

Money for Couples: Make Smart Money Choices Now So You Can Enjoy Your Life Together

Posted by Emma

The one thing that couples fight about more than anything is money.

What’s interesting is that for some reason money doesn’t come up once when they’re dating. Or they figure that “it will all work out and that love conquers all.”

Yes, love does conquer all, but love is not what couples feel when they’re dating. Love is what is created after couples give to each other for years and develop and deep meaningful relationship – despite the other’s seeming “flaws.”

  • Read more about Money for Couples: Make Smart Money Choices Now So You Can Enjoy Your Life Together

Improve Your Relationship

Posted by Emma

Besides for learning about the differences between men and women, there is allot of other things you can do to enhance the quality of your relationship.

Many of these things are just basic acts of courtesy that we should be giving to all people, like saying excuse me and thank you and polite gestures like that. It might seem silly to play "formal" with the person you live with every day. But research has shown, and I can definitely vouch for this from my own personal experience, that these things do make a difference.

Posted by Emma

We all want to have deep, loving communication in our relationships. Here’s a list of 5 relationship communication experts who are bring unique techniques to we can all use to develop the best relationships possible.

Alison Armstrong

 

Alison Armstrong is a relationship communication master who does an outstanding job explaining men and women. Her material is so clear and illuminating that the opposite sex will actually understand it!

Finding Time for Yourself In a Relationship

Posted by Emma

In every relationship, learning the art of Personal Alone Time is a key to maintaining harmony. The same is true in dating and marriage. Besides for being a part of plain old common courtesy, it also gives both people the space to be unique individuals as well as loving partners.

Two Marriages - Which One Is More Tragic?

Posted by Emma

In the past week, I have heard of two divorces of people I know. Both were tragic, but one more so than the other. How do I mean?

The first story was of a close friend of mine, married for six years with 2 kids. My friend struggled with her husband from the beginning, and after numerous attempts at therapy it became clear that she was dealing with more than the “usual” type of marital issues.

Why Work Pulls Men Away; The Power Struggle With Your Partner’s Job, Redefined

Posted by Emma

One of the most common things that bother women it their partner’s obsession with his job. We feel threatened by their obsession with their work- what about us? And more often than not, the result is a power struggle, tension and unhappiness.

It seems crazy that we should have to fight for attention against a job! Why do men get so consumed with their work? Aren’t we more important? I thought he loves me….?
